intro: Celtis rubrovenia, commonly known as the red-veined hackberry, is a deciduous tree native to parts of Central and South America. It belongs to the Cannabaceae family and is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves with prominent red veins. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers that are clustered in catkins, followed by small, round berries that turn from green to dark purple as they mature. Celtis rubrovenia typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and can reach heights of up to 20 meters. It is often found in tropical and subtropical regions, where it plays a role in local ecosystems by providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
